newsitem.title: INDIA: India's Congress party a force despite scars.
newsitem.headline: India's Congress party a force despite scars.

text.p: India's Congress party, boosted by the entry of Sonia Gandhi into its ranks on Thursday, wields tremendous influence in the country's politics despite a recent history of corruption scandals and electoral defeat.

The Congress saw the entry of the Italian-born widow of former prime minister Rajiv Gandhi into the party as a much-needed tonic for millions of cadres at a time when its image had been sullied and social base eroded.
Sonia's entry is symbolic but comes in a powerful tradition of Rajiv, his mother, Indira Gandhi, and her father, Jawaharlal Nehru, whose charisma has ruled the world's biggest democracy.
The three ruled India as prime ministers for 38 of the 50 years since independence. Congress has ruled for all but five years since independence.
With 140 deputies in the 545-member lower house, the Congress last month forced the minority United Front to change its prime minister from H.D. Deve Gowda to Inder Kumar Gujral.
The Congress derives its strength from independence leader Mahatma Gandhi, whose name still inspires awe across India. Nehru was his political heir and India's first prime minister.
Formed in 1885 by an Englishman, Allan Octavian Hume, the Congress grew from being a lobby of traders and civil servants fighting discrimination under British rule to a mass movement.

Mahatma Gandhi, who saw the Congress as a movement, wanted it to be dissolved after independence, but its leaders turned the organisation into a monolithic party that cleverly exploited divisions linked to caste and regional and economic ideologies.

But the party's fortunes began slipping after Rajiv Gandhi's assassination during an election rally in 1991 by a female suicide bomber, believed to be a Sri Lankan separatist opposed to the Indian army's help for Colombo in 1987.
Then prime minister P.V. Narasimha Rao took over the reins of the party, which regained power in the elections after 18 months on the strength of a sympathy wave linked to Gandhi's murder.
But despite broad support for Rao's foreign policies and free-market economic policies, Congress was thrown out of office in general elections last year in its worst-ever showing.
Rao's personal style was seen as dour and colourless, and corruption scandals involving leaders made matters worse.

The Congress had in the past suffered shocks, especially after Indira Gandhi's electoral defeat in 1977 after two years of a controversial emergency rule. But the Gandhi family's image and charisma helped the party stage comebacks.
Nehru and Indira Gandhi carefully nourished huge vote banks among minority Moslems and low castes.
But Rajiv Gandhi was seen by many as living off his family's political wealth. New parties under aggressive low-caste leaders filled a vacuum created by his inexperience.
Moslems were seen leaving the Congress for what they saw as its ineffectiveness in checking Hindu fundamentalism.
Many Sikhs, too, left Congress. They accuse it of sparking anti-Sikh riots in 1984 after Indira Gandhi was gunned down by Sikh bodyguards.
Congress polled 28.8 percent of the vote in last year's general elections -- the first time it fell below 30 percent.
